meanings.def: to receive something
examples: I got a call from Dave this morning.
What (= What presents) did you get for your birthday?
He gets (= earns) about $40 000 a year.
This room gets very little sunshine.
I got a shock when I saw the bill.
I will report back when I get a chance.
I get the impression that he is bored with his job.
Where did you get the idea from?
It's the best way to get a sense of what's actually going on here.
She got great satisfaction from seeing his embarrassment.

meanings.def: to obtain something
examples: He has just got a new job.
I'll get the money somehow.
She opened the door wider to get a better look.
Try to get some sleep.
You can also get information on careers in social work from their website.
I think someone's trying to get your attention.
She really knows how to get results.

meanings.def: to buy something
examples: get something Where did you get that skirt?
Did you manage to get tickets for the concert?
(North American English) Can I get a Coke? For example, when ordering in a cafe or restaurant. In British English, we are more likely to say: Can I have a Coke?
get something for somebody Did you get a present for your mother?
get somebody/yourself something Did you get your mother a present?
Why don't you get yourself a car?
$100 will get you the basic model.
You can get yourself the basic model for $100.

meanings.def: to obtain or receive an amount of money by selling something
examples: get something If you sell it at auction you can expect to get roughly £800.
get something for something How much did you get for your car?
We got £420 000 for the house.

meanings.def: to go to a place and bring somebody/something back
examples: get somebody/something Quick—go and get a cloth!
Somebody get a doctor!
She went to get help.
I have to go and get my mother from the airport (= collect her).
get something for somebody Get a drink for John.
get somebody/yourself something Get John a drink.
She's gone to get a few more chairs.
Could you go upstairs and get my wallet for me, please?
Can I get you anything to eat or drink?

meanings.def: to achieve or be given a particular mark or grade in an exam
examples: He got a ‘C’ in Chemistry and a ‘B’ in English.

meanings.def: to start to develop an illness; to suffer from a pain, etc.
examples: I got this cold off (= from) you!
She gets (= often suffers from) really bad headaches.
I think I'm getting a cold.

meanings.def: to receive something as a punishment
examples: He got ten years (= was sent to prison for ten years) for armed robbery.

meanings.def: to connect to the internet or a phone network; to receive broadcasts from a particular television or radio station
examples: 95 per cent of the UK can now get superfast broadband.
I couldn't get any mobile phone reception.
We can't get Channel 5 in our area.

meanings.def: to be connected with somebody by phone
examples: I wanted to speak to the manager but I got his secretary instead.

meanings.def: to arrive at or reach a place or point
examples: We got to San Diego at 7 o'clock.
We're aiming to get to the party at about nine.
You got in very late last night.
I got back an hour ago.
Wait till we get home.
What time did you get here?
Let me know when you get there.
I haven't got very far with the book I'm reading.

meanings.def: to move to or from a particular place or in a particular direction, sometimes with difficulty; to make somebody/something do this
examples: + adv./prep. The bridge was destroyed so we couldn't get across the river.
She got into bed.
He got down from the ladder.
We didn't get (= go) to bed until 3 a.m.
Where do we get on the bus?
I'm getting off (= leaving the train) at the next station.
Where have they got to (= where are they)?
We must be getting home; it's past midnight.
get somebody/something + adv./prep. We couldn't get the piano through the door.
We'd better call a taxi and get you home.
The general had to get his troops across the river.
I can't get the lid off.
How can we get to the other side of town?
I don't know how he managed to get down from the roof.
It takes an hour to get from Oxford to London.
We only got as far as the next town.
You can get to the hotel by bus or taxi.

meanings.def: to use a bus, taxi, plane, etc.
examples: We're going to be late—let's get a taxi.
I usually get the bus to work.
Get a train to Newport and then get a bus from the station.
He got the next plane home.
I ran all the way to the station and just managed to get my train.
I'll try and get a flight home tomorrow.
You won't be able to get a plane there—there's no airport.

meanings.def: to reach a particular state or condition; to make somebody/something/yourself reach a particular state or condition
examples: + adj. to get angry/bored/hungry/fat
to get better/worse
You'll soon get used to the climate here.
We ought to go; it's getting late.
to get dressed/undressed (= to put your clothes on/take your clothes off)
They plan to get married in the summer.
She's upstairs getting ready.
As he's got older his tastes have changed.
She was getting sick of hearing him complain.
There's nothing to get excited about.
He got drunk and passed out.
I was starting to get tired.
I wouldn't go there alone; you might get (= be) mugged.
My car got (= was) stolen at the weekend.
get somebody/something + adj. Don't get your dress dirty!
He got his fingers caught in the door.
She soon got the children ready for school.

meanings.def: to reach the point at which you feel, know, are, etc. something
examples: After a time you get to realize that these things don't matter.
You'll like her once you get to know her.
His drinking is getting to be a problem.
She's getting to be an old lady now.

meanings.def: to cause something to happen or be done
examples: I must get my hair cut.
I'll never get all this work finished.
She has a reputation for getting things done.

meanings.def: to make, persuade, etc. somebody/something to do something
examples: get somebody/something to do something I couldn't get the car to start this morning.
He got his sister to help him with his homework.
You'll never get him to understand.
get somebody/something doing something It's not hard to get him talking—the problem is stopping him!
Can you really get that old car going again?
I finally got Michael to talk to them and he explained everything.
We had trouble getting enough people to sign up.

meanings.def: to start doing something
examples: I got talking to her.
We need to get going soon.

meanings.def: to have the opportunity to do something
examples: He got to try out all the new software.
It's not fair—I never get to go first.

meanings.def: to prepare a meal
examples: get something Who's getting the lunch?
You sit down and relax. I'll get supper.
get something for somebody/yourself I must go home and get tea for the kids.
get somebody/yourself something I must go home and get the kids their tea.

meanings.def: to answer the phone or a door when somebody calls, knocks, etc.
examples: Will you get the phone?

meanings.def: to catch or take hold of somebody, especially in order to harm or punish them
examples: He was on the run for a week before the police got him.
to get somebody by the arm/wrist/throat
She fell overboard and the sharks got her.
He thinks everybody is out to get him (= trying to harm him).
(informal) I'll get you for that!

meanings.def: to hit or wound somebody
examples: The bullet got him in the neck.

meanings.def: to understand somebody/something
examples: I don't get you.
She didn't get the joke.
I don't get it—why would she do a thing like that?
I get the message—you don't want me to come.
I don’t understand the instructions.
Doctors still don’t understand much about the disease.
‘It opens like this.’ ‘Oh, I see.’
Oh yes, I see what you mean.
She didn’t get the joke.
I don’t get you.
Sorry—I don’t quite follow.
The plot is almost impossible to follow.
They failed to grasp the importance of his words.
The concept of infinity is almost impossible for the human mind to comprehend.

meanings.def: used to say that something happens or exists
examples: You get (= There are) all these kids hanging around in the street.
They still get cases of typhoid there.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel confused because they do not understand something
examples: ‘What's the capital of Bhutan?’ ‘You've got me there!’ (= I don't know)

meanings.def: to annoy somebody
examples: What gets me is having to do the same thing all day long.

meanings.def: to be becoming old
to be becoming late
examples: The time's getting on—we ought to be going.

meanings.def: to be nearly a particular time, age or number
examples: It must be getting on for midnight.
He's getting on for eighty.

meanings.def: used to say that you are shocked, surprised, etc. by something
examples: I can't get over how rude she was.

meanings.def: to have a short holiday in a place where you can relax
to leave a place in order to go somewhere else
examples: It's been lovely to see you, but it's probably time we got going.

meanings.def: to start happening or being done
examples: The project hasn't really got going yet.

meanings.def: to make somebody angry, worried or excited
to succeed in starting a machine, vehicle, process, etc.
examples: We finally managed to get the car going.

meanings.def: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something
examples: If your dad finds out you'll really get it!

meanings.def: to have sex with somebody
to have an erection
to not help somebody make progress or succeed
examples: This line of investigation is getting us nowhere.
Being rude to me won't get you anywhere.

meanings.def: to make some progress/no progress
examples: After six months' work on the project, at last I feel I'm getting somewhere.
I don't seem to be getting anywhere with this letter.

meanings.def: to achieve your aim or complete a task
examples: I'm sure you'll get there in the end.
It's not perfect but we're getting there (= making progress).

meanings.def: used to say that you are going to tell somebody something that they will find surprising or interesting
examples: OK, get this guys—there are only two left!
So get this—I did all the work and he got the money.

meanings.def: used to express surprise or disapproval that somebody has been so selfish, stupid, etc.
you have to admit that something unpleasant is true
used to ask, especially in an angry way, what somebody is/was suggesting
examples: I'm partly to blame? What exactly are you getting at?

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has suddenly started to behave in a strange or different way
examples: What's got into Alex? He never used to worry like that.
I’m sorry for laughing like that—I don’t know what got into me.
The time's getting on—we ought to be going.

idioms.def: to be nearly a particular time, age or number
examples: It must be getting on for midnight.
He's getting on for eighty.

idioms.def: used to say that you are shocked, surprised, etc. by something
examples: I can't get over how rude she was.

idioms.def: to have a short holiday in a place where you can relax
to leave a place in order to go somewhere else
examples: It's been lovely to see you, but it's probably time we got going.
The project hasn't really got going yet.

idioms.def: to make somebody angry, worried or excited
to succeed in starting a machine, vehicle, process, etc.
examples: We finally managed to get the car going.

idioms.def: to be punished or spoken to angrily about something
examples: If your dad finds out you'll really get it!

idioms.idiom: get somebody nowhere/not get somebody anywhere
idioms.def: to not help somebody make progress or succeed
examples: This line of investigation is getting us nowhere.
Being rude to me won't get you anywhere.
After six months' work on the project, at last I feel I'm getting somewhere.
I don't seem to be getting anywhere with this letter.

idioms.def: to achieve your aim or complete a task
examples: I'm sure you'll get there in the end.
It's not perfect but we're getting there (= making progress).

idioms.def: used to say that you are going to tell somebody something that they will find surprising or interesting
examples: OK, get this guys—there are only two left!
So get this—I did all the work and he got the money.

idioms.idiom: how selfish, stupid, ungrateful, etc. can you get?
idioms.def: used to express surprise or disapproval that somebody has been so selfish, stupid, etc.

idioms.idiom: there’s no getting away from something | you can’t get away from something
idioms.def: you have to admit that something unpleasant is true

idioms.idiom: what are you, was he, etc. getting at?
idioms.def: used to ask, especially in an angry way, what somebody is/was suggesting
examples: I'm partly to blame? What exactly are you getting at?

idioms.def: used to say that somebody has suddenly started to behave in a strange or different way
examples: What's got into Alex? He never used to worry like that.
I’m sorry for laughing like that—I don’t know what got into me.
